A. Minimal Square

time limit per test2 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
Find the minimum area of a square land on which you can place two identical rectangular ğ‘Ã—ğ‘ houses. The sides of the houses should be parallel to the sides of the desired square land.

Formally,

You are given two identical rectangles with side lengths ğ‘ and ğ‘ (1â‰¤ğ‘,ğ‘â‰¤100) â€” positive integers (you are given just the sizes, but not their positions).
Find the square of the minimum area that contains both given rectangles. Rectangles can be rotated (both or just one), moved, but the sides of the rectangles should be parallel to the sides of the desired square.
Two rectangles can touch each other (side or corner), but cannot intersect. Rectangles can also touch the sides of the square but must be completely inside it. You can rotate the rectangles. Take a look at the examples for a better understanding.

The picture shows a square that contains red and green rectangles.
Input
The first line contains an integer ğ‘¡ (1â‰¤ğ‘¡â‰¤10000) â€”the number of test cases in the input. Then ğ‘¡ test cases follow.

Each test case is a line containing two integers ğ‘, ğ‘ (1â‰¤ğ‘,ğ‘â‰¤100) â€” side lengths of the rectangles.

Output
Print ğ‘¡ answers to the test cases. Each answer must be a single integer â€” minimal area of square land, that contains two rectangles with dimensions ğ‘Ã—ğ‘.

Example
inputCopy
8
3 2
4 2
1 1
3 1
4 7
1 3
7 4
100 100
outputCopy
16
16
4
9
64
9
64
40000
Note
Below are the answers for the first two test cases:

B. Honest Coach

time limit per test2 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
There are ğ‘› athletes in front of you. Athletes are numbered from 1 to ğ‘› from left to right. You know the strength of each athlete â€” the athlete number ğ‘– has the strength ğ‘ ğ‘–.

You want to split all athletes into two teams. Each team must have at least one athlete, and each athlete must be exactly in one team.

You want the strongest athlete from the first team to differ as little as possible from the weakest athlete from the second team. Formally, you want to split the athletes into two teams ğ´ and ğµ so that the value |max(ğ´)âˆ’min(ğµ)| is as small as possible, where max(ğ´) is the maximum strength of an athlete from team ğ´, and min(ğµ) is the minimum strength of an athlete from team ğµ.

For example, if ğ‘›=5 and the strength of the athletes is ğ‘ =[3,1,2,6,4], then one of the possible split into teams is:

first team: ğ´=[1,2,4],
second team: ğµ=[3,6].
In this case, the value |max(ğ´)âˆ’min(ğµ)| will be equal to |4âˆ’3|=1. This example illustrates one of the ways of optimal split into two teams.

Print the minimum value |max(ğ´)âˆ’min(ğµ)|.

Input
The first line contains an integer ğ‘¡ (1â‰¤ğ‘¡â‰¤1000) â€” the number of test cases in the input. Then ğ‘¡ test cases follow.

Each test case consists of two lines.

The first line contains positive integer ğ‘› (2â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤50) â€” number of athletes.

The second line contains ğ‘› positive integers ğ‘ 1,ğ‘ 2,â€¦,ğ‘ ğ‘› (1â‰¤ğ‘ ğ‘–â‰¤1000), where ğ‘ ğ‘– â€” is the strength of the ğ‘–-th athlete. Please note that ğ‘  values may not be distinct.

Output
For each test case print one integer â€” the minimum value of |max(ğ´)âˆ’min(ğµ)| with the optimal split of all athletes into two teams. Each of the athletes must be a member of exactly one of the two teams.

Example
inputCopy
5
5
3 1 2 6 4
6
2 1 3 2 4 3
4
7 9 3 1
2
1 1000
3
100 150 200
outputCopy
1
0
2
999
50
Note
The first test case was explained in the statement. In the second test case, one of the optimal splits is ğ´=[2,1], ğµ=[3,2,4,3], so the answer is |2âˆ’2|=0.

C. Similar Pairs

time limit per test2 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
We call two numbers ğ‘¥ and ğ‘¦ similar if they have the same parity (the same remainder when divided by 2), or if |ğ‘¥âˆ’ğ‘¦|=1. For example, in each of the pairs (2,6), (4,3), (11,7), the numbers are similar to each other, and in the pairs (1,4), (3,12), they are not.

You are given an array ğ‘ of ğ‘› (ğ‘› is even) positive integers. Check if there is such a partition of the array into pairs that each element of the array belongs to exactly one pair and the numbers in each pair are similar to each other.

For example, for the array ğ‘=[11,14,16,12], there is a partition into pairs (11,12) and (14,16). The numbers in the first pair are similar because they differ by one, and in the second pair because they are both even.

Input
The first line contains a single integer ğ‘¡ (1â‰¤ğ‘¡â‰¤1000) â€” the number of test cases. Then ğ‘¡ test cases follow.

Each test case consists of two lines.

The first line contains an even positive integer ğ‘› (2â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤50) â€” length of array ğ‘.

The second line contains ğ‘› positive integers ğ‘1,ğ‘2,â€¦,ğ‘ğ‘› (1â‰¤ğ‘ğ‘–â‰¤100).

Output
For each test case print:

YES if the such a partition exists,
NO otherwise.
The letters in the words YES and NO can be displayed in any case.

Example
inputCopy
7
4
11 14 16 12
2
1 8
4
1 1 1 1
4
1 2 5 6
2
12 13
6
1 6 3 10 5 8
6
1 12 3 10 5 8
outputCopy
YES
NO
YES
YES
YES
YES
NO
Note
The first test case was explained in the statement.

In the second test case, the two given numbers are not similar.

In the third test case, any partition is suitable.

D. Buying Shovels

time limit per test2 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
Polycarp wants to buy exactly ğ‘› shovels. The shop sells packages with shovels. The store has ğ‘˜ types of packages: the package of the ğ‘–-th type consists of exactly ğ‘– shovels (1â‰¤ğ‘–â‰¤ğ‘˜). The store has an infinite number of packages of each type.

Polycarp wants to choose one type of packages and then buy several (one or more) packages of this type. What is the smallest number of packages Polycarp will have to buy to get exactly ğ‘› shovels?

For example, if ğ‘›=8 and ğ‘˜=7, then Polycarp will buy 2 packages of 4 shovels.

Help Polycarp find the minimum number of packages that he needs to buy, given that he:

will buy exactly ğ‘› shovels in total;
the sizes of all packages he will buy are all the same and the number of shovels in each package is an integer from 1 to ğ‘˜, inclusive.
Input
The first line contains an integer ğ‘¡ (1â‰¤ğ‘¡â‰¤100) â€” the number of test cases in the input. Then, ğ‘¡ test cases follow, one per line.

Each test case consists of two positive integers ğ‘› (1â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤109) and ğ‘˜ (1â‰¤ğ‘˜â‰¤109) â€” the number of shovels and the number of types of packages.

Output
Print ğ‘¡ answers to the test cases. Each answer is a positive integer â€” the minimum number of packages.

Example
inputCopy
5
8 7
8 1
6 10
999999733 999999732
999999733 999999733
outputCopy
2
8
1
999999733
1
Note
The answer to the first test case was explained in the statement.

In the second test case, there is only one way to buy 8 shovels â€” 8 packages of one shovel.

In the third test case, you need to buy a 1 package of 6 shovels.

E. Polygon

time limit per test2 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
Polygon is not only the best platform for developing problems but also a square matrix with side ğ‘›, initially filled with the character 0.

On the polygon, military training was held. The soldiers placed a cannon above each cell in the first row and a cannon to the left of each cell in the first column. Thus, exactly 2ğ‘› cannons were placed.

Initial polygon for ğ‘›=4.
Cannons shoot character 1. At any moment of time, no more than one cannon is shooting. When a 1 flies out of a cannon, it flies forward (in the direction of the shot) until it collides with a polygon border or another 1. After that, it takes the cell in which it was before the collision and remains there. Take a look at the examples for better understanding.

More formally:

if a cannon stands in the row ğ‘–, to the left of the first column, and shoots with a 1, then the 1 starts its flight from the cell (ğ‘–,1) and ends in some cell (ğ‘–,ğ‘—);
if a cannon stands in the column ğ‘—, above the first row, and shoots with a 1, then the 1 starts its flight from the cell (1,ğ‘—) and ends in some cell (ğ‘–,ğ‘—).
For example, consider the following sequence of shots:

  1. Shoot the cannon in the row 2. 2. Shoot the cannon in the row 2. 3. Shoot the cannon in column 3.

You have a report from the military training on your desk. This report is a square matrix with side length ğ‘› consisting of 0 and 1. You wonder if the training actually happened. In other words, is there a sequence of shots such that, after the training, you get the given matrix?

Each cannon can make an arbitrary number of shots. Before the training, each cell of the polygon contains 0.

Input
The first line contains an integer ğ‘¡ (1â‰¤ğ‘¡â‰¤1000) â€” the number of test cases. Then ğ‘¡ test cases follow.

Each test case starts with a line containing an integer ğ‘› (1â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤50) â€” the size of the polygon.

This is followed by ğ‘› lines of length ğ‘›, consisting of 0 and 1 â€” the polygon matrix after the training.

The total area of the matrices in all test cases in one test does not exceed 105.

Output
For each test case print:

YES if there is a sequence of shots leading to a given matrix;
NO if such a sequence does not exist.
The letters in the words YES and NO can be printed in any case.

Example
inputCopy
5
4
0010
0011
0000
0000
2
10
01
2
00
00
4
0101
1111
0101
0111
4
0100
1110
0101
0111
outputCopy
YES
NO
YES
YES
NO
Note
The first test case was explained in the statement.

The answer to the second test case is NO, since a 1 in a cell (1,1) flying out of any cannon would continue its flight further.

å¥½ä¹…æ²¡å†™åšå®¢äº†

A. Orac and Factors
time limit per test2 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
Orac is studying number theory, and he is interested in the properties of divisors.

For two positive integers ğ‘ and ğ‘, ğ‘ is a divisor of ğ‘ if and only if there exists an integer ğ‘, such that ğ‘â‹…ğ‘=ğ‘.

For ğ‘›â‰¥2, we will denote as ğ‘“(ğ‘›) the smallest positive divisor of ğ‘›, except 1.

For example, ğ‘“(7)=7,ğ‘“(10)=2,ğ‘“(35)=5.

For the fixed integer ğ‘›, Orac decided to add ğ‘“(ğ‘›) to ğ‘›.

For example, if he had an integer ğ‘›=5, the new value of ğ‘› will be equal to 10. And if he had an integer ğ‘›=6, ğ‘› will be changed to 8.

Orac loved it so much, so he decided to repeat this operation several times.

Now, for two positive integers ğ‘› and ğ‘˜, Orac asked you to add ğ‘“(ğ‘›) to ğ‘› exactly ğ‘˜ times (note that ğ‘› will change after each operation, so ğ‘“(ğ‘›) may change too) and tell him the final value of ğ‘›.

For example, if Orac gives you ğ‘›=5 and ğ‘˜=2, at first you should add ğ‘“(5)=5 to ğ‘›=5, so your new value of ğ‘› will be equal to ğ‘›=10, after that, you should add ğ‘“(10)=2 to 10, so your new (and the final!) value of ğ‘› will be equal to 12.

Orac may ask you these queries many times.

Input
The first line of the input is a single integer ğ‘¡ (1â‰¤ğ‘¡â‰¤100): the number of times that Orac will ask you.

Each of the next ğ‘¡ lines contains two positive integers ğ‘›,ğ‘˜ (2â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤106,1â‰¤ğ‘˜â‰¤109), corresponding to a query by Orac.

It is guaranteed that the total sum of ğ‘› is at most 106.

Output
Print ğ‘¡ lines, the ğ‘–-th of them should contain the final value of ğ‘› in the ğ‘–-th query by Orac.

Example
inputCopy
3
5 1
8 2
3 4
outputCopy
10
12
12
Note
In the first query, ğ‘›=5 and ğ‘˜=1. The divisors of 5 are 1 and 5, the smallest one except 1 is 5. Therefore, the only operation adds ğ‘“(5)=5 to 5, and the result is 10.

In the second query, ğ‘›=8 and ğ‘˜=2. The divisors of 8 are 1,2,4,8, where the smallest one except 1 is 2, then after one operation 8 turns into 8+(ğ‘“(8)=2)=10. The divisors of 10 are 1,2,5,10, where the smallest one except 1 is 2, therefore the answer is 10+(ğ‘“(10)=2)=12.

In the third query, ğ‘› is changed as follows: 3â†’6â†’8â†’10â†’12.

A

B. Orac and Models
time limit per test3 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
There are ğ‘› models in the shop numbered from 1 to ğ‘›, with sizes ğ‘ 1,ğ‘ 2,â€¦,ğ‘ ğ‘›.

Orac will buy some of the models and will arrange them in the order of increasing numbers (i.e. indices, but not sizes).

Orac thinks that the obtained arrangement is beatiful, if for any two adjacent models with indices ğ‘–ğ‘— and ğ‘–ğ‘—+1 (note that ğ‘–ğ‘—<ğ‘–ğ‘—+1, because Orac arranged them properly), ğ‘–ğ‘—+1 is divisible by ğ‘–ğ‘— and ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘—<ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘—+1.

For example, for 6 models with sizes {3,6,7,7,7,7}, he can buy models with indices 1, 2, and 6, and the obtained arrangement will be beautiful. Also, note that the arrangement with exactly one model is also considered beautiful.

Orac wants to know the maximum number of models that he can buy, and he may ask you these queries many times.

Input
The first line contains one integer ğ‘¡ (1â‰¤ğ‘¡â‰¤100): the number of queries.

Each query contains two lines. The first line contains one integer ğ‘› (1â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤100000): the number of models in the shop, and the second line contains ğ‘› integers ğ‘ 1,â€¦,ğ‘ ğ‘› (1â‰¤ğ‘ ğ‘–â‰¤109): the sizes of models.

It is guaranteed that the total sum of ğ‘› is at most 100000.

Output
Print ğ‘¡ lines, the ğ‘–-th of them should contain the maximum number of models that Orac can buy for the ğ‘–-th query.

Example
inputCopy
4
4
5 3 4 6
7
1 4 2 3 6 4 9
5
5 4 3 2 1
1
9
outputCopy
2
3
1
1
Note
In the first query, for example, Orac can buy models with indices 2 and 4, the arrangement will be beautiful because 4 is divisible by 2 and 6 is more than 3. By enumerating, we can easily find that there are no beautiful arrangements with more than two models.

In the second query, Orac can buy models with indices 1, 3, and 6. By enumerating, we can easily find that there are no beautiful arrangements with more than three models.

In the third query, there are no beautiful arrangements with more than one model.

B

Codeforces Round #634 (Div. 3)

A

A. Candies and Two Sisters(é¢˜ç›®é“¾æ¥)
A. Candies and Two Sisters
time limit per test1 second
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
There are two sisters Alice and Betty. You have ğ‘› candies. You want to distribute these ğ‘› candies between two sisters in such a way that:

Alice will get ğ‘ (ğ‘>0) candies;
Betty will get ğ‘ (ğ‘>0) candies;
each sister will get some integer number of candies;
Alice will get a greater amount of candies than Betty (i.e. ğ‘>ğ‘);
all the candies will be given to one of two sisters (i.e. ğ‘+ğ‘=ğ‘›).
Your task is to calculate the number of ways to distribute exactly ğ‘› candies between sisters in a way described above. Candies are indistinguishable.

Formally, find the number of ways to represent ğ‘› as the sum of ğ‘›=ğ‘+ğ‘, where ğ‘ and ğ‘ are positive integers and ğ‘>ğ‘.

You have to answer ğ‘¡ independent test cases.

Input
The first line of the input contains one integer ğ‘¡ (1â‰¤ğ‘¡â‰¤104) â€” the number of test cases. Then ğ‘¡ test cases follow.

The only line of a test case contains one integer ğ‘› (1â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤2â‹…109) â€” the number of candies you have.

Output
For each test case, print the answer â€” the number of ways to distribute exactly ğ‘› candies between two sisters in a way described in the problem statement. If there is no way to satisfy all the conditions, print 0.

Example
inputCopy
6
7
1
2
3
2000000000
763243547
outputCopy
3
0
0
1
999999999
381621773
Note
For the test case of the example, the 3 possible ways to distribute candies are:

ğ‘=6, ğ‘=1;
ğ‘=5, ğ‘=2;
ğ‘=4, ğ‘=3.

B. Construct the String(é¢˜ç›®é“¾æ¥)
B. Construct the String
time limit per test2 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
You are given three positive integers ğ‘›, ğ‘ and ğ‘. You have to construct a string ğ‘  of length ğ‘› consisting of lowercase Latin letters such that each substring of length ğ‘ has exactly ğ‘ distinct letters. It is guaranteed that the answer exists.

You have to answer ğ‘¡ independent test cases.

Recall that the substring ğ‘ [ğ‘™â€¦ğ‘Ÿ] is the string ğ‘ ğ‘™,ğ‘ ğ‘™+1,â€¦,ğ‘ ğ‘Ÿ and its length is ğ‘Ÿâˆ’ğ‘™+1. In this problem you are only interested in substrings of length ğ‘.

Input
The first line of the input contains one integer ğ‘¡ (1â‰¤ğ‘¡â‰¤2000) â€” the number of test cases. Then ğ‘¡ test cases follow.

The only line of a test case contains three space-separated integers ğ‘›, ğ‘ and ğ‘ (1â‰¤ğ‘â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤2000,1â‰¤ğ‘â‰¤min(26,ğ‘)), where ğ‘› is the length of the required string, ğ‘ is the length of a substring and ğ‘ is the required number of distinct letters in each substring of length ğ‘.

It is guaranteed that the sum of ğ‘› over all test cases does not exceed 2000 (âˆ‘ğ‘›â‰¤2000).

Output
For each test case, print the answer â€” such a string ğ‘  of length ğ‘› consisting of lowercase Latin letters that each substring of length ğ‘ has exactly ğ‘ distinct letters. If there are multiple valid answers, print any of them. It is guaranteed that the answer exists.

Example
inputCopy
4
7 5 3
6 1 1
6 6 1
5 2 2
outputCopy
tleelte
qwerty
vvvvvv
abcde
Note
In the first test case of the example, consider all the substrings of length 5:

â€œtleelâ€: it contains 3 distinct (unique) letters,
â€œleeltâ€: it contains 3 distinct (unique) letters,
â€œeelteâ€: it contains 3 distinct (unique) letters.

C

C. Two Teams Composing(é¢˜ç›®é“¾æ¥)
C. Two Teams Composing
time limit per test2 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
You have ğ‘› students under your control and you have to compose exactly two teams consisting of some subset of your students. Each student had his own skill, the ğ‘–-th student skill is denoted by an integer ğ‘ğ‘– (different students can have the same skills).

So, about the teams. Firstly, these two teams should have the same size. Two more constraints:

The first team should consist of students with distinct skills (i.e. all skills in the first team are unique).
The second team should consist of students with the same skills (i.e. all skills in the second team are equal).
Note that it is permissible that some student of the first team has the same skill as a student of the second team.

Consider some examples (skills are given):

[1,2,3], [4,4] is not a good pair of teams because sizes should be the same;
[1,1,2], [3,3,3] is not a good pair of teams because the first team should not contain students with the same skills;
[1,2,3], [3,4,4] is not a good pair of teams because the second team should contain students with the same skills;
[1,2,3], [3,3,3] is a good pair of teams;
[5], [6] is a good pair of teams.
Your task is to find the maximum possible size ğ‘¥ for which it is possible to compose a valid pair of teams, where each team size is ğ‘¥ (skills in the first team needed to be unique, skills in the second team should be the same between them). A student cannot be part of more than one team.

You have to answer ğ‘¡ independent test cases.

Input
The first line of the input contains one integer ğ‘¡ (1â‰¤ğ‘¡â‰¤104) â€” the number of test cases. Then ğ‘¡ test cases follow.

The first line of the test case contains one integer ğ‘› (1â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤2â‹…105) â€” the number of students. The second line of the test case contains ğ‘› integers ğ‘1,ğ‘2,â€¦,ğ‘ğ‘› (1â‰¤ğ‘ğ‘–â‰¤ğ‘›), where ğ‘ğ‘– is the skill of the ğ‘–-th student. Different students can have the same skills.

It is guaranteed that the sum of ğ‘› over all test cases does not exceed 2â‹…105 (âˆ‘ğ‘›â‰¤2â‹…105).

Output
For each test case, print the answer â€” the maximum possible size ğ‘¥ for which it is possible to compose a valid pair of teams, where each team size is ğ‘¥.

Example
inputCopy
4
7
4 2 4 1 4 3 4
5
2 1 5 4 3
1
1
4
1 1 1 3
outputCopy
3
1
0
2
Note
In the first test case of the example, it is possible to construct two teams of size 3: the first team is [1,2,4] and the second team is [4,4,4]. Note, that there are some other ways to construct two valid teams of size 3.

D. Anti-Sudoku(é¢˜ç›®é“¾æ¥)
D. Anti-Sudoku
time limit per test2 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
You are given a correct solution of the sudoku puzzle. If you donâ€™t know what is the sudoku, you can read about it here.

The picture showing the correct sudoku solution:

Blocks are bordered with bold black color.

Your task is to change at most 9 elements of this field (i.e. choose some 1â‰¤ğ‘–,ğ‘—â‰¤9 and change the number at the position (ğ‘–,ğ‘—) to any other number in range [1;9]) to make it anti-sudoku. The anti-sudoku is the 9Ã—9 field, in which:

Any number in this field is in range [1;9];
each row contains at least two equal elements;
each column contains at least two equal elements;
each 3Ã—3 block (you can read what is the block in the link above) contains at least two equal elements.
It is guaranteed that the answer exists.

You have to answer ğ‘¡ independent test cases.

Input
The first line of the input contains one integer ğ‘¡ (1â‰¤ğ‘¡â‰¤104) â€” the number of test cases. Then ğ‘¡ test cases follow.

Each test case consists of 9 lines, each line consists of 9 characters from 1 to 9 without any whitespaces â€” the correct solution of the sudoku puzzle.

Output
For each test case, print the answer â€” the initial field with at most 9 changed elements so that the obtained field is anti-sudoku. If there are several solutions, you can print any. It is guaranteed that the answer exists.

E1. Three Blocks Palindrome
E1. Three Blocks Palindrome (easy version)
time limit per test3 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
The only difference between easy and hard versions is constraints.

You are given a sequence ğ‘ consisting of ğ‘› positive integers.

Letâ€™s define a three blocks palindrome as the sequence, consisting of at most two distinct elements (let these elements are ğ‘ and ğ‘, ğ‘ can be equal ğ‘) and is as follows: [ğ‘,ğ‘,â€¦,ğ‘î„½î„¾î…î…‹î…‹ğ‘¥,ğ‘,ğ‘,â€¦,ğ‘î„½î„¾î…î…‹î…‹ğ‘¦,ğ‘,ğ‘,â€¦,ğ‘î„½î„¾î…î…‹î…‹ğ‘¥]. There ğ‘¥,ğ‘¦ are integers greater than or equal to 0. For example, sequences [], [2], [1,1], [1,2,1], [1,2,2,1] and [1,1,2,1,1] are three block palindromes but [1,2,3,2,1], [1,2,1,2,1] and [1,2] are not.

Your task is to choose the maximum by length subsequence of ğ‘ that is a three blocks palindrome.

You have to answer ğ‘¡ independent test cases.

Recall that the sequence ğ‘¡ is a a subsequence of the sequence ğ‘  if ğ‘¡ can be derived from ğ‘  by removing zero or more elements without changing the order of the remaining elements. For example, if ğ‘ =[1,2,1,3,1,2,1], then possible subsequences are: [1,1,1,1], [3] and [1,2,1,3,1,2,1], but not [3,2,3] and [1,1,1,1,2].

Input
The first line of the input contains one integer ğ‘¡ (1â‰¤ğ‘¡â‰¤2000) â€” the number of test cases. Then ğ‘¡ test cases follow.

The first line of the test case contains one integer ğ‘› (1â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤2000) â€” the length of ğ‘. The second line of the test case contains ğ‘› integers ğ‘1,ğ‘2,â€¦,ğ‘ğ‘› (1â‰¤ğ‘ğ‘–â‰¤26), where ğ‘ğ‘– is the ğ‘–-th element of ğ‘. Note that the maximum value of ğ‘ğ‘– can be up to 26.

It is guaranteed that the sum of ğ‘› over all test cases does not exceed 2000 (âˆ‘ğ‘›â‰¤2000).

Output
For each test case, print the answer â€” the maximum possible length of some subsequence of ğ‘ that is a three blocks palindrome.

Example
